facts.text: C. I. Emden filed an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Gajendragadkar, J. This appeal by special leave has been filed by C. I. Emden  hereinaf

facts.text: C. I. Emden convicted under s. 161 IPC and s. 5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: inafter called the appellant  who has been companyvicted under s. 161 of the Indian Penal Code and under s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act 2 of 1947  hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: C. I. Emden accepted a bribe of Rs. 375 from Sarat Chandra Shukla on January 8, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The case against him was that he had accepted a bribe of Rs. 375 from Sarat Chandra Shukla on January 8, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant was Loco Foreman at Alambagh Loco Shed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a Loco Foreman at Alambagh Loco Shed, and Shukla had secured a companytract at the same place for the removal of cinders from ash pits and for loading companyl.

facts.text: Shukla secured contract at Alambagh for removal of cinders from ash pits and loading coal in June 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and Shukla had secured a companytract at the same place for the removal of cinders from ash pits and for loading companyl. This companytract had been given to Shukla in June 1952.

facts.text: Appellant demanded Rs. 400 per month from Shukla to allow peaceful contract execution without harassment.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that the appellant demanded from Shukla Rs. 400 per month in order that Shukla may be allowed to carry out his companytract peacefully without any harassment.

facts.text: Appellant told Shukla that Ram Ratan paid monthly bribe for similar contract.

anchor.surface_text: Shukla was told by the appellant that he had been receiving a monthly payment from Ram Ratan who had held a similar companytract before him and that it would be to his interest to agree to pay the bribe.

facts.text: Shukla refused to pay bribe, leading to hostile acts by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Shukla, however, refused to accede to this request and that led to may hostile acts on the part of the appellant.

facts.text: On January 3, 1953, appellant asked Shukla to pay monthly bribe, agreed to reduce to Rs. 375.

anchor.surface_text: On January 3, 1953, the appellant again asked Shukla to pay him the monthly bribe as already suggested Shukla then requested him to reduce the demand on the ground that the companytract given to him was for a much lesser amount than that which had been given to his predecessor Ram Ratan the appellant thereupon agreed to accept Rs. 375.

facts.text: Shukla approached Deputy Superintendent of Police, Corruption Branch, informed about demand.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile Shukla approached the Deputy Superintendent of Police, Corruption Branch, and gave him information about the illegal demand made by the appellant.

facts.text: Shukla's statement recorded before magistrate, trap laid.

anchor.surface_text: Shuklas statement was then recorded before a magistrate and it was decided to lay a trap.

facts.text: Raiding party including Shukla, magistrate, Dy SP went to Loco Yard on January 8, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, a party companysisting of Shukla, the magistrate, the Deputy Superintendent of Police and some other persons went to the Loco Yard.

facts.text: Shukla gave Rs. 375 marked currency notes to appellant at about 3 p.m. in secluded place.

anchor.surface_text: He then asked Shukla to pay the money and Shukla gave him a bundle companytaining the marked currency numberes of the value of Rs. 375. A signal was then made by Shukla and the raiding party immediately arrived on the scene.

facts.text: Raiding party recovered marked currency notes from appellant's pocket.

anchor.surface_text: The magistrate disclosed his identity to the appellant and asked him to produce the amount paid to him by Shukla. The appellant then took out the currency numberes from his pocket and handed them over to the magistrate.

facts.text: Appellant admitted receiving Rs. 375 from Shukla but claimed it was a loan for children's clothing expenses.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied the charge. He admitted that he had received Rs. 375 from Shukla but his case was that at his request Shukla had advanced the said amount to him by way of loan for meeting the expenses of the clothing of his children who were studying in school.

facts.text: Appellant alleged he requested Kishan Chand for Rs. 500 loan, Shukla offered Rs. 375.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant alleged that since he had been in need of money he had requested Kishan Chand to arrange for a loan of Rs. 500 but knowing about his need Shukla offered to advance him the loan, and it was as such loan that Shukla paid him Rs. 375 and the appellant accepted the said amount.

facts.text: Special Judge convicted appellant, sentenced 1 year RI and Rs.500 fine under s.161 IPC, 2 years RI under s.5 PCA, concurrent.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the learned judge companyvicted the appellant of both the offences charged and sentenced him to suffer one years rigorous imprisonment and to pay a fine of Rs. 500 under s. 161 of the Code and two years rigorous imprisonment under s. 5 of the Act. Both the sentences were ordered to run companycurrently.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed appeal, upheld conviction on presumption under s.4, reduced s.5 sentence to 1 year RI.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court saw numberreason to interfere with the order under appeal because it held that, on the facts of the case, a statutory presumption under s. 4 had to be raised and that the said presumption had number been rebutted by the appellant. ... the sentence under s. 5 2  of the Act was reduced to one year.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave placed before Constitution Bench.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the present appeal by special leave has been preferred by the appellant. This appeal has been placed before a Constitution Bench

facts.text: Prevention of Corruption Act passed in 1947 to prevent bribery and corruption.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed in 1947 with the object of effectively preventing bribery and companyruption.

facts.text: Special Judge believed Shukla's evidence, found corroborated, rejected defence story as improbable.

anchor.surface_text: The learned special judge who tried the case believed the evidence given by Shukla, held that it was sufficiently companyroborated, and found that the defence story was improbable and untrue.

facts.text: High Court found appellant had bank balance of Rs.1600 and salary Rs.600/month.

anchor.surface_text: It has found that at the material time the appellant was in possession of a bank balance of Rs. 1,600 and that his salary was about Rs. 600 per month.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.4(1) of Act constitutional, not violating Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, number hesitation in holding that the challenge to the vires of s. 4 1  on the ground that it violates Art. 14 of the Constitution must fail.
This appeal by special leave has been filed by C. I. Emden

issues.text: whether s. 4(1) of the Act which requires a presumption to be raised against an accused person is unconstitutional and ultra vires as it violates the fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 14 of the Constitution

issues.text: When does the statutory presumption fall to be raised under s. 4(1), and what is the content of the said presumption?

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the question of companystruing s. 4 1 . When does the statutory presumption fall to be raised, and what is the companytent of the said presumption ?

arguments.claim: s. 4(1) of the Act is unconstitutional and ultra vires as it violates Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been placed before a Constitution Bench because one of the points which the appellant raises for our decision is that s. 4 1  of the Act which requires a presumption to be raised against an accused person is unconstitutional and ultra vires as it violates the fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 14 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Art. 14 permits reasonable classification with rational nexus; public servants receiving gratification form intelligible differentia related to anti-corruption object; cites Dalmia precedent

arguments.claim: The statutory presumption under s. 4(1) cannot be raised merely on proof of receipt of Rs. 375; prosecution must prove it was paid and accepted as bribe

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Anthony contends that the statutory presumption cannot be raised merely on proof of the fact that the appellant had received Rs. 375 from Shukla in order to justify the raising of the statutory presumption it must also be shown by the prosecution that the amount was paid and accepted as by way of bribe.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: provides inter alia that if a public servant accepts any gratification whatever other than legal remuneration as a motive or reward for doing or forbe

arguments.court_reasoning: Gratification means any satisfaction, not confined to bribe; proved by mere acceptance other than legal remuneration; supported by dictionary meaning, s.161 para 3, harmony with valuable thing clause for s.165; rejects need for incriminating character

arguments.claim: Onus on accused to rebut presumption under s.4(1) is lighter than prosecution's; discharged by preponderance of probabilities or reasonably probable explanation, not beyond reasonable doubt

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Anthony contends that even if the statutory presumption is raised against the appellant, in deciding the question as to whether the contrary is proved within the meaning of s. 4 1  it must be borne in mind that the onus of proof on the appellant is not as heavy as it is on the prosecution in a criminal trial.

arguments.court_reasoning: Assumes in favor that reasonably probable explanation rebuts presumption but finds appellant's explanation improbable based on evidence and circumstances

arguments.claim: Rs. 375 received from Shukla was a loan for children's clothing expenses, not bribe

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied the charge. He admitted that he had received Rs. 375 from Shukla but his case was that at his request Shukla had advanced the said amount to him by way of loan for meeting the expenses of the clothing of his children who were studying in school.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: aiding party immediately arrived on the scene. The magistrate disclosed his identity to the appellant and asked him to produce the amount paid to him

arguments.court_reasoning: Special Judge and HC found improbable and untrue; SC upheld as explanation unreasonable given bank balance, salary, no urgency, strained relations

arguments.claim: Word 'gratification' requires proof of something more than mere receipt of money; must prove received by way of bribe

anchor.surface_text: The use of the word gratification emphasises that it is not the receipt of any money which justifies the raising of the presumption something more than the mere receipt of money has to be proved. It must be proved that the money was received by way of bribe.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: pported by the decision of the Rajasthan High Court in The State v. Abhey Singh as well as the decision of the Bombay High Court in the State v. Pandu

arguments.court_reasoning: Gratification not restricted to pecuniary per s.161 p3; literal meaning suffices; otherwise presumption superfluous

arguments.claim: Presumption triggered by mere receipt of gratification other than legal remuneration; no need to prove bribe

anchor.surface_text: No doubt it is conceded by none that in most of the cases it would be the payment of money which would cause gratification to the accused but he contests the suggestion that the word gratification must be confined only to the payment of money coupled with the right that the money should have been paid by way of a bribe.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y gratification or to gratifications estimable in money. Therefore gratification mentioned in s. 4 1  cannot be companyfined only to payment of money.

arguments.court_reasoning: Adopts this view; aligns with scheme, s.161, s.165 clause

arguments.claim: Onus to disprove presumption under s.4(1) follows Evidence Act s.3 and s.4; no relaxation

anchor.surface_text: The High Court saw no reason to interfere with the order under appeal because it held that, on the facts of the case, a statutory presumption under s. 4 had to be raised and that the said presumption had not been rebutted by the appellant.

arguments.claim: s.4(1) constitutional under Art.14 as based on reasonable classification of public servants with rational nexus to anti-corruption object

anchor.surface_text: Art. 14 does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation no doubt it forbids class legislation but if it appears that the impugned legislation is based on a reasonable classification founded on intelligible differentia and that the said differentia have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by it, its validity cannot be successfully challenged under Art. 14

arguments.claim: Presumption under s.4(1) arises on proof of acceptance of gratification other than legal remuneration without proving it was motive/reward

anchor.surface_text: What the prosecution has to prove before asking the court to raise a presumption against an accused person is that the accused person has received a gratification other than legal remuneration if it is shown, as in the present case it has been shown, that the accused received the stated amount and that the said amount was not legal remuneration then the condition prescribed by the section is satisfied.

arguments.claim: Appellant's loan explanation not reasonably probable; hence presumption not rebutted

anchor.surface_text: We are prepared to assume in favour of the appellant that even if the explanation given by him is a reasonably probable one the presumption raised against him can be said to be rebutted. But is the explanation given by him reasonably probable ?

holdings.text: The challenge to the vires of s. 4(1) on the ground that it violates Art. 14 of the Constitution must fail.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, number hesitation in holding that the challenge to the vires of s. 4 1  on the ground that it violates Art. 14 of the Constitution must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 14 permits reasonable classification founded on intelligible differentia with rational relation to legislative object; public servants accepting gratification form such class related to anti-corruption goal; follows Dalmia precedent.

holdings.text: The statutory presumption under s. 4(1) falls to be raised upon proof that accused accepted gratification other than legal remuneration; no need to prove it was paid/accepted as bribe; gratification not confined to pecuniary bribe.

anchor.surface_text: What the prosecution has to prove before asking the court to raise a presumption against an accused person is that the accused person has received a gratification other than legal remuneration if it is shown, as in the present case it has been shown, that the accused received the stated amount and that the said amount was not legal remuneration then the condition prescribed by the section is satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual meaning of gratification per dictionary and s.161 para 3; harmonious construction with valuable thing clause for s.165; purposive to ease bribery proof without superfluity.

holdings.text: In the present case, High Court was justified in raising presumption under s.4(1) against appellant as he admitted receiving Rs.375 from Shukla, other than legal remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold that in the present appeal the High Court was justified in raising the presumption against the appellant because it is admitted by him that he received Rs. 375 from Shukla and that the amount thus received by him was other than legal remuneration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show acceptance of marked notes recovered; admitted receipt; not legal remuneration.

holdings.text: Appellant's explanation that Rs.375 was loan for children's clothing is improbable and unreasonable; presumption under s.4(1) not rebutted; conviction upheld.

anchor.surface_text: We are prepared to assume in favour of the appellant that even if the explanation given by him is a reasonably probable one the presumption raised against him can be said to be rebutted. But is the explanation given by him reasonably probable ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sufficient bank balance Rs.1600 and salary Rs.600/month; no urgency as school starts March; strained/hostile relations with Shukla; defence witnesses unreliable like Kishan Chand.

holdings.text: Not necessary to decide standard of proof to rebut s.4(1) presumption; even assuming reasonably probable explanation suffices, appellant's fails.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think it necessary to decide this point in the present appeal. We are prepare to assume in favour of the appellant that even if the explanation given by him is a reasonably probable one the presumption raised against him can be said to be rebutted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumes lighter onus (preponderance/probable) per precedents like Carr-Briant but explanation improbable on evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Otto George Gfeller v. The King  A.I.R. 1943 P.C. 211  the Privy Council was dealing with the case where the prosecution had established that the accused were in possession of goods recently stolen and the point which arose for decision was how the explanation given by the accused about his possession of the said goods would or should be companysidered by the jury.

precedents.case_name: Otto George Gfeller v. The King
precedents.cited_proposition: Accused does not have to prove story to rebut presumption; if story breaks down, conviction may follow; explanation assessed for reasonableness

anchor.surface_text: Rex v. Carr Briant   1943  1 K.B. 607  where it has been observed that in any case where either by statute or at companymon law some matter is presumed against an accused, unless the companytrary is proved the jury should be directed that it is for them to decide whether the companytrary is proved, that the burden of proof required is less than that required at the hands of the prosecution in proving the case beyond a reasonable doubt, and that the burden may be discharged by evidence satisfying the jury of the probability of that which the accused is called upon to establish  p. 612 .
